This paper explores t,echniques for visualizing collections of oriait,a.t,ions. An orieiila,tion map represents orientmations as positions in 3-space. A typical use of an orient,at,ion map is to find clusters of crystals that are aligned siniilarly, or t*o watch how a particle rotates into a. new oricwt.a.t,ion as it is influenced by a magnetic field. The dist.ance between two orientat,ions is t8he sinallest, anglc through which one orientation must rota.t,e t.o prodwe t,he other. A good orieiitatioii map should be fait81ifiil bot,h t.0 this distance measure and to other aspects of the mathematical structure of the set of all possible orientations.

There is a direct correspondence between orientations and rotations: once a reference orientation has been fixed, any other orientation is uniquely identified by the rotation that transforms the reference orientation into it. This identification will be exploited mercilessly in what follows. Particularly useful will be the transformation induced by changing froni one reference orientation to another. This operation will be called reoncntatzon.

A helpful analogy exists between orientation maps and maps of the Earth's surface [P90]. An Earth map represents places on the Earth, topologically a 2-sphere, as positions on a piece of paper, a (usually bounded) region of 2-space. As will be explained below, rotations can be identified with pairs of dianietrically opposed points on a 3-sphere (the points of unit distance from the origin in 4-space). Orientation maps represent points on the top half of the 3-sphere a s positions in a (usually bounded) region of 3-space.l An obvious problem with any Earth map concerns the boundary: for instance, as one moves East on the Earth one eventually falls off the right-hand edge of a map and reappears on the left. Such problems are unavoidable for orientation maps as well '. It is not particularly difficult for a viewer to become familiar with the boundary's peculiar topology.

The Earth has a number of geometric properties (distanccs, angles, areas, etc.). Earth maps can be evaluated by how well such properties are preserved. For instance, the Mercator Projection draws both lines of latitude and of longitude as straight lines. It distorts the latitude scale in such a way that the map is conformal, that is, the angle between three nearby3 'points on the map will be nearly the same as the angle bet,ween t,he corresponding points on the Earth's surface. Counterbalancing this desirable property of the Mercator Projection are its distortion of areas (e.g., Greenland and Antarctica appear huge), and the fact that the shortest path between two points on the Earth (an arc of a great circle) is not mapped as a straight, line. A map that is perfectly faithful to one geometric property necessarily distorts others. The same is true of orientation maps. This paper is intended t,o be a guide to the selection of a satisfactory orient,ation map.
The next, section rehearses ma,thematical properties of rot,ations. Section 3 reviews six orientation maps.

Section 4 establishes bounds on the distortion inherent in these maps. Section 5 describes our investigation into the appropriateness of these maps for visualizin,g orient,at,ions. The final section presents our conclusions. An a.ppendix considers a notion of rotation appropriate to quantum physics.

div.head: The Matheiliatics of Rotations
div.p: In two papers in 1775, Euler established most of the mathematics of rotation^.^ The first showed that any rotat.ion could be accomplished by a sequence of three rotations about coordinate axes. This is the basis for the Euler angle orientation map. The second paper offered a different, characterization of rotations: every rotation is shown to be a rotation of some angle Q around some fixed axis 11. This characterization is the basis for neo-Eulerian orientation maps [F88].

Euler's second paper also proved, although not constructively, that the composition of t,wo rotations is a rotatmion. This is the key to establishing that the rotations form a group with the null rotation as the identity and composition as the operator. This group is identical to t,he group of orthonormal 3 x 3 matrices with determinant. 1 called the Special Orthonormal group SO(3).
A technique for constructing the composition of two rotations was given by Rodrigues in 1840. For The norm of such quaternions is 1, so they represent points on the 3-sphere.
It is easy to establish that opposite points on the 3-sphere correspond to the same rotation: the quater-

The fixed axis characterization of rotations also provides a natural notion of the distance between rotations. Given a clockwise rotation around some fixed axis n of angle Q with 0 5 Q 5 x that takes rotation A to rotation B , the rotational distance between A and B is Q. Also, the set of rotations formed by composing a rotation of any angle about n to rotation A is the projective line through A and B . Any additional rotation C not on this line determines the projective plane containing A , B , and C.

div.head: Orientation Maps
div.p: Traditionally, rotations are parameterized by Euler angles.6 A rotation is represented by a triple ( a , p, y) with -ir < (Y 5 ir, 0 L p 5 x , and -ir < y 5 x .

The triple denotes the following sequence of clockwise rotations: first, by y around the z-axis, then by /3 around the y-axis, and finally by a around the z-axis. Although any rotation can be so represented, this representation is not unique when /? is either 0 or ir. This orientation map also badly distorts the geometry of rot at ions. The null rotation is represented by the zero vector. Following Frank [F88], such orientation maps will be called neo-Eukrzan. Except for the unbounded stereographic orientation map, each of the neo-Eulerian maps represents the set of all orientations by the set of points inside and on the surface of a unit ball in 3-space. Because antipodal rotations are identified, antipodal points on the surface of a neo-Eulerian map are also identified.

div.head: Bounds on Distortion
div.p: Any method of mapping the set of rotations into 3-space must distort distances to some extent, but the neo-Eulerian maps described above differ in the amount of distortion introduced. To study the distortions, consider any orientation P , and let Q be the orientation resulting from rotating P through angle 4

around the x-axis. Thus, the rotational distance between P and Q is 4, but the distance between P and Q on an orientation map will depend on the location of P . This section studies how the mapped distance varies as P is moved through the set of possible orientations. In particular, we will find the maximum ratio of map distances between orientations at rotational distance 4. (Only placements of P and Q for which the shortest path from P to Q does not cross through the surface of the map are considered.)
Three placements of P and Q are of particular interest. The first has P and Q being equidistant from the origin of the orientation map along the x-axis.

In this case, they are mapped as PI = (-f($),O,O) and Q1 = (f($),O,O), where f is the scaling function of the orientation map. In the second case, P appears on the surface at P2 = ( -l , O , 0 ) , and Q will be at Q2 = ( f (~ -#),O,O). In the final case, with P3 = (0,1,0) and Q3 = (0, cos($), sin($)), both lie on the surface of the map.

For each of the five neo-Eulerian maps, it can be shown that both the maximum and minimum mapped distances between P and Q occur for one of the three placements described above. Thus, the greatest distortion of distance will be the ratio of two of these distances. Given an orientation map, define the radial dilation to be the ratio of the distance between P2 and Q2 to the distance between PI and Q1. Thus, it is the factor by which a segment of the z-axis grows as it is moved from the center toward the surface of the orientation map. Similarly, define circumferential dilation to be the ratio of the distance between P3 and Q3 to the distance between P2 and 9 2 . Thus, it is the dilation experienced by a line segment when it moves from being perpendicular to the surface (with one end on the surface) to lying entirely on the surface.

For each of the orientation maps under consideration, the radial and circumferential dilations are most extreme for very short segments. For instance, a small equilateral triangle will grow as it moves from the center to the surface, but it will remain equilateral. With the other techniques, the triangle's angles are distorted.
In this case, the other maps will also have little distortion. The possible benefit of the stereographic map is that projective lines are mapped to straight lines and projective planes to planes.

div.head: Visualizing Triangles of Orientations
div.p: To get a better feel for the various orientation maps the authors built an apparatus for viewing them using IBM's Data Explorer (DX) visualization software.8 With this system, we studied the effect of changing the reference orientation on standard figures in the various maps. We use equilateral triangles of orientations of differing sizes as our standard figures.

div.head: Radial Circumferential
div.p: In the Euler angle orientation map, the reference orientation is not represented by a unique point but by the line ( a , 0, -a). Thus, a figure in standard position looks more like a rectangle than a triangle. Under a sequence of reorientations (by rotati6ns around the y-axis of increasing magnitude) the figure changes shape wildly. The most that can be said is that the figure remains contiguous except when it leaves one boundary of the map and reappears through another. The strengths and weaknesses of the different Orientation Maps are summarized in Figure 1. Three of the four finite neo-Eulerian orientation maps considered seem to be nearly equally viable candidates for visualizing orient,at,ions. The orthographic orientation map is only slightly less so. This is somewhat disappointing. We had hoped to be able to point to one map as being clearly better than the other three. On the other hand, it leaves researchers free to choose an orientation map for reasons intrinsic to their research without fear of compromising their ability to visualize t,heir results.

div.head: Appendix: Tethered Rot at ions
div.p: A somewhat different notion of rotation arises in quantuin mechanics. When an electron is rotated 2n it,s wave funct,ion is negated. [A861 This leads physicists to take t.he view that a rotat,ion of 47r is required to attain the null rotatmion. The term idhered rotation is sometimes used to denote this concept. A tethered rotation is characterized by a fixed unit vector and an angle of clockwise rotation between 0 and 2x. The space of kthered rotations corresponds to the 3-sphere witshout any ident#ifica.tion of points.

Neo-Eulerian maps can be coerced to represent t,et,hered rotat,ions by extending the domain of the scaling function to [0,2n]. In extended orthographic and st(ereograp1iic orientat,ion maps, each point represents two tethered rotations. They could be differentiated by the use of two different colors; a user must remember t,hat points of opposite color are far apart unless they are both near the same boundary point.

The extended conformal orientation map provides unique representat,ions but is unbounded. This map has the interesting property that projective planes map to spheres (and projective lines to circles). Such spheres intersect the unit sphere (that is the boundary of the conformal orientation map proper) in great circles [F92].

The extended linear and volumetric orientation maps are bounded and provide unique representations.
